text: We're watching footage of the 1985 Redskins/Giants Monday Night Football game. Lots of angles, faces, knuckles as t two teams line up, Redskins on offense, for the snap of t ball. As the play begins --

One Mississippi. Joe Theismann, the Redskins quarterback, takes the snap and hands off to his running back. JOE THEISMANN hands off to JOHN RIGGINS, who takes two st forward, then turns and tosses the ball back'to Theismann The footage PAUSES AND PLAYS like a coach breaking down f

Two Mississippi. It's a trick play, a flea flicker, and the running back tosses the ball back to the quarterback. HARRY CARSON, the Giants linebacker sees that Theismann h the ball back and races toward him. Theismann steps up an to the side and Carson flies past.

Three Mississippi. Up to now the play's been defined by what the quarterback sees. It's about to be defined by what he doesn't. LAWRENCE TAYLOR carves a wide circle around the Redskins lineman trying to block him.
The blocker dives frantically. at Taylor's ankles, and mi Taylor leaps, arms raised, filling the sky behind Theisma The image FREEZES.

Four Mississippi. Lawrence Taylor is the best defensive player in the NFL and has been from the time he stepped onto the field as a rookie. The frozen image of Taylor comes to life as he jackknifes Theismann's body. PLAYERS' FACES react to what they're seeing. Devastating. TAYLOR pops up from the pile and jumps around like a madm
He will also change the game of football as we know it. WE ARE WATCHING the MNF feed and hear the ANNOUNCER'S VOI
Again, we'll look at it with the reverse angle one more time. And I suggest if your stomach is weak you just don't watch.
Joe Theissman never played another down of football.

head_text.subj: TEAM PHOTO OF THE 2005 SEATTLE SEAHAWKS 3

text: Now, y'all would guess that more often than not the highest paid player on an NFL team is the quarterback. The camera finds MATT HASSELBECK, Seattle's quarterback.

And you'd be right. What you probably don't know is that more often than not the second highest paid player is, thanks to Lawrence Taylor, a left tackle. The camera goes to WALTER JONES, Seattle's left tackle.

Because, as every housewife knows, the first check you write is for the mortgage and the second is for the insurance. The left tackle's job is to protect the quarterback from what he can't see coming. To protect his blind side.
"Famous" left tackles - Jonathan Ogden, Orlando Pace, And Gurode. Then we SEE SHOTS of their hands, feet, waists, etc., corresponding with ---
The ideal left tackle is big, but a lot of people are big. He is wide in the butt and massive in the thighs. He has long arms, giant hands and feet as quick as a hiccup.

A street anchored by project housing and littered with br down cars and ne'er-do-wells. Lots of folks out, milling about, but our focus is on A TEENAGER in the distance, mo TOWARD US in SLO-MO while everyone else is at normal spee He's extremely large, six and a half feet, but he careful steps instead of strutting. His name is MICHAEL OHER.

This is a rare and expensive combination the need for which can be traced to that Monday night game and Lawrence. Taylor. For on that day he not only altered Joe Theismann's life, but mine as well. As Michael continues toward us he begins to go OUT OF FOC
Mr. Oher, do you know why I'm here?
Mr. Oher?...
Do you know, do you understand why I'm here?
To... investigate.
Yes. To investigate. I'm here to investigate your odd... predicament.

Looks like a government office. Not much more than a desk either side of which sit INVESTIGATOR GRANGER, an African American woman in a business suit, and Michael Oher. Mich slumps a bit, eyes the ground and rubs his hands on his k - a nervous trait of his.
Do you find it odd? Your predicament?
Michael?...

Iono [I don't know]... Investigator Granger sifts through her briefcase, pulls o files, documents - a good bit of evidence for whatever trouble Michael is in. She sits back, stares at Michael, as if trying to figure out. Michael can't meet her gaze. He looks out the window rubs his knees some more.
Can I... can I leave now?
No. You can't.
Michael sits in the back seat, behind STEVEN HAMILTON, 14 and his father, BIG TONY, who drives.
Not a word is spoken as they drive through the streets of WEST MEMPHIS - poverty ridden. 8
The Taurus exits into --

location: SOMEWHAT NICER AREA OF TOWN.- DAY 9

text: The Taurus passes an endless supply of churches and strip joints, all of which Michael's eyes take in.

We've gone from slums to nice neighborhoods - fathers and sons play baseball, kids tend lemonade stands, sprinklers keep the grass emerald green. Michael's face tells us he's never seen anything like thi
The Taurus enters the parking lot filled with nice cars. A12
Big Tony strides down the almost empty hallway, spots a d
BERT COTTON, football coach, cleans off his desk, ready t leave for the day. Big Tony knocks at the door. BIG TONY
They say you the coach. Cotton eyes Tony, offers a hand. COTTON
Bert Cotton. BIG TONY
Tony Hamilton, but everybody call me Big Tony. COTTON
What can I do for you, Tony?
Steven and Michael eye the freshly painted buildings, the flowers, the new playground jungle gyms and outdoor hoops (CONTINUED)
6 13 CONTINUED: 13 STEVEN
Sure is pretty, huh, Big Mike? Mike doesn't answer, just takes it all in. Steven sees an opens a container filled to the brim with balls - footbal basketballs, four square balls. STEVEN (CONT'D)
Not even locked! MICHAEL
White people are crazy.
Big Tony and Cotton are mid-discussion --- BIG TONY
You see I promised my mama Boo, on her deathbed, that I would get Steven outta public and into a church school. COTTON
I appreciate that but I'm not involved with admissions. BIG TONY
I figured I'd come to you; seeing as you might need some players. COTTON
What sport does he play? BIG TONY
Anything with a ball. Good, too. He has Cotton's attention for a moment, then it passes... COTTON
Classes start in a week. It'd have to be for next semester. BIG TONY
I know what you're thinking, Coach, but I got money. I'm a mechanic at Wilson's Auto t'other side of town. (ANOTHER TRY)
What if someone drops out or moves? Could they get in then? (CONTINUED)
7 14 CONTINUED: 14 COTTON
"They?" You only mentioned one son. BIG TONY
Steven, yessir, but I brought another boy along. COTTON
Another boy? BIG TONY
Yeah, Big Mike. He stays on our couch sometimes. It's a bad deal. His mama's on the crack pipe and he ain't got nobody. He just wanted to come along with us today. COTTON
Would... Big Mike be an applicant as well? BIG TONY
Yeah, sure, why not. Cotton sighs, considers what to do. COTTON
They'd have to fill out applications and make an appointment for interviews. BIG TONY
I was hopin' you might just interview 'em now. COTTON
They're here? Big Tony points out the.window to the playground where St and Michael are playing one on one basketball. BIG TONY
The little ones Steven and the big ONE'S -- COTTON
Big Mike. BIG TONY
Yeah. That's right. INTERCUT WITH:

For a boy his size Michael can really move. He dribbles, fakes left, then falls away, making a long three pointer. Cotton's eyes get a little wider as he watches -- Michael dribbles the ball between his legs, behind his ba and jumps high, slamming the ball through the hoop. Big m aren't supposed to move like this. Cotton's lips are almost quivering -- COTTON
Mother of God...
The Board of Admissions, eight or so men and women, are seated around a large conference table. By himself, at on end, sits Bert Cotton.  COTTON
Are there spots available or not? PAUL SANDSTROM, Principal, taps his fingers before...  SANDSTROM

Technically, yes, in both grades. But we have a greater responsibility than just filling classrooms. Steven Hamilton's  paperwork looks acceptable and I believe he would be capable of succeeding here but the other kid -- Sandstrom looks through papers for the name.  COTTON
Big Mike. SANDSTROM
Michael Oher gives us no reason to believe, based on his record, that he would be successful here. COTTON
How bad could it be? Another board member, MRS. SMITH, pores over Michael's fi which is a mess. She finds facts and lays them out --- (CONTINUED)
9 16 CONTINUED: 16

We're not sure exactly how old he is due to lack of records. He has a measured IQ of 80. That's 6th percentile. He's been enrolled in seven different institutions, including a gap of eighteen months around the age of ten when he apparently didn't attend school at all. He repeated first grade as well as second, there's no record of attendance in third, and in fourth grade -- COTTON
So they moved him ahead without going to third grade. That says something.
(IGNORING COTTON)
His attendance records are abysmal and his grade point average begins with a zero. Zero-point-six- Silence around the room. MRS. BOSWELL, a board member and science teacher, looks to the others.
Everyone passed him along - gave him D's so they could hand their problem off to the next school. COTTON

Brave kid. (off their confusion) For wanting to come here. For wanting a quality education. An education denied him by the poor quality of the schools he's attended. Most kids with his background wouldn't come within two hundred miles of this place.
Coach Cotton, we understand your interest in the young man's athletic abilities. SANDSTROM
He wouldn't be able to play until he got his grades up anyway. (CONTINUED)
The Blind Side - Green Revision - 04/28/09 10 16 CONTINUED: 16 COTTON
Forget sports! Look at the wall. He points to the crest on the wall. Beneath it: "NEIGHBOR ACADEMIC, CHRISTIAN". COTTON (CONT'D)
Christian. We either take that seriously or we paint over it. You don't admit Michael Oher for sports, you admit him because it's the right thing to do. Their faces announce that he's made a point.

First day of class. Students, mostly blonde-haired and bl eyed, wearing crisply laundered Abercrombie and Fitch, ca their backpacks through the school's arch and converse wi friends they haven't seen over the summer. Michael ENTERS FRAME. Fills it up in fact. He stares at t arch. Beneath the school name we read "WITH MEN THIS IS. POSSIBLE, WITH GOD ALL THINGS ARE POSSIBLE". Michael take deep breath and enters. He carries his "school bag" - a plastic grocery sack.

Just as before, Michael moves at A DIFFERENT SPEED than t around him. Makes sense because he is different. Not only the color of his skin but his size, his clothes (short pa and T-shirt), his eyes taking in the pavement - all point the fact that he doesn't belong here. Small children from kindergarten and first grade give him wide, cautious berth. He's noticed and ogled by everyone.

It's Mrs. Boswell's biology class and she's writing on th board in front of a full classroom when Michael enters. H pauses and all eyes go to him. Mrs. Boswell does her best stifle a gasp as she first lays eyes on him. Then...
Class, this is Mike Oher and he's new here so I expect you all to make him feel welcome. (with a warm smile) Mike, take any empty seat. (CONTINUED)
11 19 CONTINUED: 19

She urges him with a nod. Michael walks back and sits in corner, looking terrified. He barely fits in the seat. Mrs. Boswell hands out a stack of papers to each row. As students pass them back to others...
This is a quiz based on the information you learned last year in your science curriculum. (OVER GROANS)

Don't worry. It won't be graded. I just want to see how much of the information we need to hit again.  Just answer whatever you know. The student in front of Michael hands a sheet back to him eyes the size of his feet. The students start to work while Michael stares at the sh like it's written in Greek. Mrs. Boswell watches him for few seconds before turning back to her work.
A bell RINGS and kids leave classrooms.

Michael sits alone while Mrs. Boswell collects the last o the papers. She walks over to Michael, looks down at his sheet. Nothing filled in, just his name scrawled at the t She tries to decide how to deal with this then opts for -
It's okay. MICHAEL

Can I leave now? She nods and watches him stand and walk away. She glances down at the sheet, turns it over and sees... A DRAWING on the back - a boat on an ocean. On the boat i single, stick figure person. It's sweet but looks like a third grader drew it. 12
Michael lies on a tattered sofa. The lights are out but Michael's eyes are open, staring at the light emanating f beneath a closed bedroom door. We hear voices...
Why he gotta always stay here?
Ain't got nowhere else.
And how's that your problem? You the Red Cross all of a sudden? Michael tries to shut his eyes. 23
School is out. Steven walks up to Michael... STEVEN
Hey, Big Mike, um... my Pops' girlfriend... she don't really want you to stay with us no more. Big Tony's Taurus pulls into the lot. STEVEN (CONT'D)
We can still give you rides if you want? MICHAEL
Naw, it's aright. Steven gets in the Taurus. Michael watches it drive away. 24

A girl's volleyball game is in progress in the bg. As latecomers move en masse for entry into the gym, a small pretty lady on a cell phone moves.against the crowd; a sa on a mission. This is LEIGH ANNE Tuohy. And she's pissed. LEIGH ANNE
(on cell phone) I don't care if Patrick Ramsey did approve the chair. He's an NFL quarterback not Martha frickin' Stewart. (CONTINUED)
The Blind Side - Green Revision - 04/28/09 13 24 CONTINUED: 24
She arrives at the concession stand and waits impatiently
There's a difference between Bunny Williams and Lazee-boy. (TO VENDOR)
Three large popcorns and two large diets. (INTO CELL)

When MTV Cribs comes to his house he'll be showing off his home theatre but all I'm gonna see is a brown Barca-lounger. I'm his designer, my name's on it. Deliver what I ordered!!! She hangs up angry, spots a friend nearby and her frown t into a smile that could light up a cave.
Hi, sweetie! We're on the Kidspace committee together, aren't we?! It'll be a hoot!

Leigh Anne's husband SEAN TUOHY, handsome, confidant, and their 10-year-old son, SJ, sit, watching the game. During a time out, Sean eyes the crowd, sees something od In the upper corner of the gym sits Michael, by himself, rubbing his knees. Others around him, all white, have mov away. He's a very large island in the lily white gym. SEAN
S.J., you know that kid? SJ
What kid? SEAN
Black kid. Up in the corner. SI
Be goes to high school here. His name is Big something... Big Mike. Sean eyes Michael suspiciously. (CONTINUED)
14 25 CONTINUED: 25 SEAN
He look like a volleyball fan to you? Leigh Anne, loaded up with refreshments, makes her way up stands to her family. She has a nod, a smile, a bon mot, everyone she passes. As she sits... LEIGH ANNE
What'd I miss? SEAN
Collins got a dig. SI
It's girl's volleyball, Mom. You didn't miss anything. Leigh Anne gives him a look then stands and shouts -- LEIGH ANNE
Collins! Move your feet! ON THE COURT - COLLINS TUOHY, a beautiful 16-year-old, si and gives her mother a look - "Don't embarrass me!"
The scoreboard tells us that the game is over. Fans file out. The Tuohy family waits in a group as the volleyball team exits the court. LEIGH ANNE
Collins, we'll wait outside. And don't double condition in the shower - you still have homework! COLLINS
I'm going over to Cannon's house to study. SI
Can I go.to the Johnson's for dinner? They invited me. LEIGH ANNE
What's so awful about our house? Sean smiles, shakes his head as SJ and Collins leave. (CONTINUED)
15 26 CONTINUED: 26

Sean's eyes go to the upper stands where he sees Michael, alone, walking slowly, then bending down, picking somethi up, taking a few more steps and repeating the process. Picking up left-over bags of popcorn. Sean considers this for a second before leaving.
Teachers drink stale coffee and chew on donuts.
Well, the big guy's been here a month and he ain't cutting it in my class.
Why would Admissions do this? It's not fair to us or the boy.
Just setting him up to fail. BOB
I don't think he has any idea what I'm teaching. GLENDA
And how would you know if he did? He won't even talk. Mrs. Boswell can't contain herself.
He writes. APRIL
His name. Barely. Mrs. Boswell goes to'her purse, pulls out a crumpled page

He threw this in the trash can. (reads from the page) "I look and I see white everywhere: white walls, white floors, and a lot of white people. The teachers do not know I have no idea of anything they are talking about. I do not want to listen to anyone, especially the teachers. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
16 27 CONTINUED: 27

They are giving homework and expecting me to do the problems on my own. I have never done homework in my life. I go to the bathroom, look in the mirror and say, "This is not Michael Oher." (a pause for effect) He entitled it "White Walls." The room is dead quiet. BOB
How's the spelling? Mrs. Boswell stuffs the page back in her purse and leaves
Sean and Coach Cotton sip coffee while all around them students eat their lunches. They are looking at Michael, sits by himself without a tray in front of him. COTTON
If he makes his grades he'll be eligible in the spring. SEAN
If he makes his grades. COTTON
But boy-hidey, just look at him. Cotton is admiring Michael's size but Sean sees something else. He stands, walks over to Michael, who barely looks SEAN
What did you eat for lunch today? MICHAEL
Here in the cafeteria. SEAN
I didn't ask where you ate, I asked what you ate. MICHAEL
A few things. SEAN
Do you need some money? For lunch? (CONTINUED)
17 28 CONTINUED: 28 MICHAEL
I don't need any. Sean walks back over to Coach Cotton. SEAN
Buy him a semester lunch pass and put it on my bill. (off Cotton's look) He's hungry. COTTON
You could tell that by looking at him? SEAN -
I didn't grow up all that different from him. At public school they give you free lunch, Bert. And when food is finite, you'd be surprised how much time you can spend thinking about it..
Mrs. Boswell distributes a test to the class.

You'll have one hour. If you finish early put it on my desk and sit quietly. She looks at the class as they begin to work, then sees Michael just staring at his test. She sighs, makes a decision, rises and walks over.
Mike, come with me.
Filled with supplies and a small desk. Mrs. Boswell point and he sits.
You can take the test back here away from everybody else. I'll sit in there so if there's anything you don't understand you can ask. (CONTINUED)
18 30 CONTINUED: 30
Michael's eyes go to the page in front of him. He rubs hi hands on his knees and stares. Mrs. Boswell waits a beat then scoots her chair over next to him.
Mike, how about I ask the questions and you tell me the answers or as much as you know. She looks at his hands - huge next to hers - then reads:
Protozoans are classified based on: a) how they get their food, b) how they reproduce, c) how they move, or d) both a and c. Michael just stares. After a long moment MICHAEL
Iono...

Just try. Ask questions if you don't understand. But still Michael stares at the page. The look on her fac says she's about to give up when He lifts his eyes to her and points to -- -- the question on the test - specifically to the word "classified".
"Classified". It means how things are grouped together. MICHAEL
Like our "class"?
Exactly. This science course is classified based on what grade y'all are in. Eleventh. Michael nods understanding.
Okay, Mike, you ready to answer the question? (CONTINUED)
19 30 CONTINUED: 30
He looks at her.
Same group of teachers. Mrs. Boswell bursts through the door, holding the test.
He knows it! BOB
Who knows it and what does he know?
The material. Michael Oher. I gave him this test verbally. She holds up the test -- marked with a large red "C". APRIL
On how big a curve?

He's been listening the whole time. It's amazing what he's absorbed. And, trust me, he's listening to you, too. Okay, so his reading level is low and he has no idea how to learn in a classroom, but... (makes her point) I'm not saying he's going to pass but Big Mike is not stupid.
School is out and Michael walks among the kids of all sha and sizes. Two little Kindergarten girls'try and swing themselves. Michael stops nearby, watching them. MICHAEL
They're stuck, not sure if they should talk to this "stranger". They jump off the swings and run away. SI (OS)
Smile at 'em. Michael turns to see Si nearby, watching him. (CONTINUED)
The Blind Side - Green Revision - 04/28/09 20 32 CONTINUED: 32 SJ (CONT'D)

It lets them know you're their friend. Did you know that even little kids born blind smile? They've never seen anyone do it before but they smile anyway. So it's universal. That's why it works. Not that you should fake it or anything... You're Big Mike, right? Sean holds. out a fist for Mike to "knock" and the two wa toward the school entrance. SJ (CONT'D)

I'm Sean, but everyone calls me Si -- that's for Sean Junior because my father's name is Sean. Sean Tuohy. He was a basketball star at Ole Miss, point guard, and now he owns like a million Taco Bells. Leigh Anne's car pulls up to the pick up/drop off and Si starts toward it. SJ (CONT'D)
Manana'. Michael smiles at the kid, who smiles back.
Leigh Anne notices Michael as she drives past him. LEIGH ANNE
Who's that SJ? SI
Big Mike. LEIGH ANNE
Get your feet off my dash.
Michael watches Leigh Anne's car disappear.
Big Mike?... (CONTINUED)
21 34 CONTINUED: 34
Michael turns to see Paul Sandstrom, the principal.
Michael and Sandstrom sit on a bench. SANDSTROM

Mike, I just got a call from someone at the police department. (off Michael's look) Do you remember the story in the papers awhile back about the man who fell off an overpass? (Michael shakes his head) No one knew who he was and they're not sure if he jumped, or if... at any rate he passed away. Sandstrom struggles with how to say the words.  SANDSTROM (CONT'D)
Mike, the man... was your father. Michael takes this in. without showing emotion. SANDSTROM (CONT'D)
They've been looking for someone to notify and came across your name on our registry. I'm really sorry, son. (NO RESPONSE)
Were you close? (Michael shakes his head) When did you last see him? MICHAEL
Iono. SANDSTROM
I'll try and find out where he's buried. Maybe we could go visit? Michael nods, then rises and walks away.
Michael sits at a bus stop with his bag, rises as a bus s in front of him. 37 OMITTED 37
The Blind Side -- Yellow Draft - 04/15/09 22

Pretty seedy. Michael walks to a sink in the back, opens plastic sack, pulls out an extra T-shirt and starts to wa it. A WOMAN, the only other patron, reads a magazine. When he turns to look at her, she becomes quite nervous. She sets down the magazine and walks outside. It seems Michael was expecting this because as soon as sh leaves he takes his wet T-shirt, wrings it-out, walks to dryer and tosses the shirt inside to dry with her things.
Michael sits in the corner, his head resting against the window, trying to sleep.  DISSOLVE TO:

A banner over the arch reads: THANKSGIVING PAGEANT TONIGH Kids in costume - Pilgrims, Indians, turkeys - race out t door to greet their proud parents. Si, in an ornate headdress looks for and spots Sean and Leigh Anne waving. They walk away together toward the parking lot.
As they exit the parking lot-- LEIGH ANNE
Turn on the heat! SEAN
I don't know where it is. LEIGH ANNE
It's fifteen degrees, you've had this car a month and you don't know how to turn on the heat?! (as she turns it on) What would you do without.me? SEAN
Lots of things you'll never know about. (CONTINUED)
23 43 CONTINUED: 43
They trade a look and a smile. Sean puts a.hand on her la SI
Get a room. LEIGH ANNE
Si, don't let this go to your head but I thought you were very convincing in the role of... uh... SI
Indian Number Three. I tried out for the Chief but they gave it to Andy Sung. I can't be sure but I think there was some multi-cultural bias thing working. SEAN
Or maybe they just thought he'd make a better Chief. SI
Dad, he's like Chinese. LEIGH ANNE
And you're Irish. If you weren't the Chief how come you got the headdress? Si hesitates a bit before -- SI
Dad, I'm gonna need a few more of those free Quesadilla tickets. LEIGH ANNE (LAUGHS)
And where does the acorn fall? SEAN
Don't laugh too hard. The Quesadilla saved our ass.
Sean's car stops at a red light and Michael crosses in fr of them, wearing just his shorts and short sleeved shirt.
Leigh Anne notices Michael -- (CONTINUED)
LEIGH ANNE
What is he wearing? It's below freezing. What's his name again?
Big Mike. LEIGH ANNE
Where's he going? She gives Sean a look. Sean rolls down his window. SEAN
Hey, Big Mike! Michael stops in the crosswalk, looks to the car. SEAN (CONT'D)
Where you headin'? MICHAEL
Gym.._. Sean nods, rolls his window back up and drives as the lig turns green. LEIGH ANNE
The gym? It's nine o'clock. No answer to this. They drive another half block,before -
Turn around. Sean sighs, knowing better than to argue.
The BMW pulls to a stop alongside Michael. Leigh Anne get out, walks up to Michael. LEIGH ANNE
Big Mike, my name is Leigh Anne Tuohy. My kids go to Wingate. You said you're going to the gym? Michael slowly nods.
The school gym's closed. Michael takes this in but doesn't respond. (CONTINUED)
25 44 CONTINUED: 44
Why were you going to the gym? (again no answer) Big Mike?! Why were you going to the gym? MICHAEL
Because... it's warm. This hits her all at once. She bites her lip. LEIGH ANNE
Do you have anywhere to stay tonight? Michael eyes the ground, then nods.
Don't you dare lie to me.
Sean and SJ watch the discussion without hearing any of i Leigh Anne looks to Sean, then back to Michael. SEAN

I've seen that look many times. She's about to get her way. Leigh Anne makes her way back to the car, with Michael in tow. She opens the back door and he gets in next to SJ in his headdress. Leigh Anne climbs into the front seat, clo the door. Sean is looking at her. SEAN (CONT'D)
Where we going? LEIGH ANNE
Home.
The car enters the driveway of a beautiful home and stops
Michael's eyes are frozen at the sight. To him it looks l a mansion. Hell, it IS a mansion. The Blind Side - Green Revision - 04/28/09 26
Collins, in her pjs, talks on the phone while watching TV listening to the stereo. She wears a tangerine cleansing masque on her face. When the family enters behind her -- COLLINS
How'd the dork do in the play? She turns to see... Sean, Leigh Anne, SJ in headdress and Big Mike. COLLINS (CONT'D)
Um... okay...
Leigh Anne lays out pillows, sheets, blankets on the couc LEIGH ANNE
I'd give you the guest bedroom but it's full of sample boxes. And the sectional in the family room slides apart when you sleep on it. At least that's what Sean says. MICHAEL
Mr. Tuohy sleeps on the couch?  LEIGH ANNE
Only when he's bad. There's a powder room right there and we're upstairs if you need us. The two share a look, then...
Sleep tight, honey. She leaves. Michael is dumbfounded, stares at everything the room, then sits on the couch. SJ
Psst... SJ is in the doorway to the kitchen. SJ (CONT'D)
If you can't sleep, my room is the first one at the top of the back stairs. I got X-Box, Madden, everything. (CONTINUED)
The Blind Side - Green Revision - 04/28/09 26A 49 CONTINUED: 49
Michael nods then smiles. SJ smiles back, gives a thumbs and disappears. Michael's eyes go to a coffee table book (CONTINUED)
27 49 CONTINUED: 49
NORMAN ROCKWELL. On the cover is "FREEDOM FROM WANT" - picturing a family sitting around a dinner table.
They lie in bed, awake. LEIGH ANNE
Was this a bad idea? SEAN
What? LEIGH ANNE
Don't lie there and pretend you're not thinking the same thing as me. SEAN
Fine, tell me what you're thinking so I can know what's supposed to be on my mind. LEIGH ANNE
How well do you know Big Mike? SEAN
In case you haven't noticed he doesn't have much to say. What's the big deal? It's just one night. (after a beat) It is just one night, right?.. Leigh Anne?... LEIGH ANNE
Do you think he'll steal anything? SEAN
I guess we'll know in. the morning. He rolls over to go to sleep. Leigh Anne just sits, stare
Leigh Anne finishes teasing her hair. Sean rides an exerc bike. Before she leaves the room... LEIGH ANNE
If you hear a scream call the insurance adjustor. 28
Leigh Anne enters Collins' bedroom. Very "teenage girl" b a mess - clothes everywhere. Leigh Anne opens the curtain throwing light into the room. LEIGH ANNE
Up and at 'em. Collins groans. Leigh Anne picks up a few pieces of cloth on her way out and groans at the mess. We stay with her a she re-enters the hallway, walks and opens the door to --
Just as messy but not all clothes. Leigh Anne almost trip on a series of wires connecting games to a large screen T LEIGH ANNE
Sean Junior! She opens the shades.
Clean this place up before you come downstairs. You hear me? Si crawls out of bed and Leigh Anne exits the room and st down the stairs, almost afraid of what she'll find.
Leigh Anne stops, stares -- The couch is totally back to normal and the sheets, blank and pillows are neatly stacked in almost military precisi No sign of Michael. LEIGH ANNE
Mike? Big Mike?! Nothing. She hears a DOG BARKING in the neighborhood and moves to the window to look out.
Michael, plastic sack in hand, walks away. Leigh Anne exi the front door, spots Michael and tries to catch up. LEIGH ANNE
Big Mike! (CONTINUED)
The Blind Side - Yellow Draft -- 04/15/09 29 55 CONTINUED: 55
He stops, turns. Leigh Anne walks over.

You closed your eyes.  He nods. She shakes her head, amazed at the kid. They sta out at the street, then...

Okay. LEIGH ANNE

A newspaper photo of a dead boy from the.projects. Then another headline, another young, black face. Another and another, until the last headline shows a photo of David, Alton's minion - his face full of shining promise.

In the last paragraph they talked about his superb athletic skills and how different his life might have been if he hadn't fallen behind and dropped out of school. He was twenty-one years old the day he died. It was his birthday.
Lonely, falling apart.
That could have been anyone. It could have been my son, Michael.
